newsitem.title: NORWAY: Profit-taking sends Norway shares lower.
newsitem.headline: Profit-taking sends Norway shares lower.

text.p: Norwegian shares fell with overseas markets amid profit-taking in slow trade on Friday, dealers said.
Oslo's Total share index dropped nearly one percent to 1,250.09 points in moderate turnover of 702 million crowns.
"We are down because of the summer lull, profit-taking, the slugging performance in overseas markets and the fact that Norsk Hydro will present results on Monday," a dealer said.
"We've had several days of new records and then it is only natural that some investors take their profits now," he said.
Hydro, which is Norway's largest listed company, fell 2.9 percent, or nine crowns, to 398 crowns after rising strongly earlier this week.
A Reuter poll of nine analysts forecast first-half pre-tax profits of 6.09 billion crowns for Hydro, slightly down from 6.14 billion crowns a year ago.
Anglo-Norwegian industrial group Kvaerner's A share fell 0.9 percent, or four crowns, to 440 crowns in weak turnover of 30 million crowns.
